Posts.Content: I had axillary clearance on 2nd October and really didn’t have much pain at all. The drain in for 5 days wasn’t comfortable so was glad when it was taken out. I developed a seroma in the area but it went down of its own accord within a week. I also developed an infection in the wound site but it cleared up with an antibiotic. The exercises were a bit uncomfortable to do at the beginning but that soon wore off. I wouldn’t worry too much as from my experience it wasn’t too bad at all.
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Mrsox! I so admire your spirit. You took time this week to cheer me up when I was feeling vulnerable when all the time you were dealing yourself with more rotten news about your own situation. You come on here with your witty posts lifting people’s spirits which in a way (I’m only hazarding a guess) might give you some respite from your own concerns. With such a spirit you’ll carry on and get there. Best wishes x PS  I’m not a member of that riff raff lot !!
Posts.Title: mrsox

Posts.Content: Am very worried. Had mammogram and ultrasound last year after finding dumpling on my left breast. Nothing showed up there but DCIS was discovered in my right breast for which I had a lumpectomy and radiotherapy. Now after my first annual mammogram I have been called back for an ultrasound scan of the left breast and axilla. Am very concerned that something was missed on the original mammogram and ultrasound scan and has now had 16 months to grow and spread. I am in my seventies and really  feel like throwing in the towel.
Posts.Title: Recall after mammogram

Posts.Content: Had ultrasound scan today which showed one swollen lymph node but nothing abnormal in breast. A biopsy was taken of node but am now worried there is cancer in breast which has not been picked up. Has anyone else been in a similar situation?
Posts.Title: Recall after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thanks for your kind wishes Shimmeringunicorn x
Posts.Title: Recall after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn for your reply. Worrying about biopsy report on lymph node due next week. Trying to push it to the back of my mind without much success.
Posts.Title: Recall after mammogram

Posts.Content: Has anyone any good stories about lymph node involvement? I’ve been really worried since being told that my path post surgery report showed 5 out of 11 nodes taken during an axillia clearance (left side) had tested positive. I’ve to see the oncologist tomorrow to discuss chemotherapy, radiotherapy and Letrozole and am to have a 6 monthly mammogram of left breast to keep a check on it as no cancer showed up in it (only in lymph nodes) on mammogram, ultrasound, MRI or CT scan. It’s the node involvement that really worries me.
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Thanks Anne. That helps to hear some people have also had a considerable amount of cancerous lymph nodes x
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Carolyn I presented at the breast clinic 20 months ago with dimpling on the left breast and mammogram and ultrasound didn’t find any evidence of cancer but DCIS was picked up in the right breast  for which I had a lumpectomy and radiotherapy. First mammogram after this in July found enlarged lymph node at the side of left breast but again mammogram, ultrasound. MRI and CT scan didn’t find anything suspicious in the left breast which I presume is why I now have to have 6 monthly mammograms of left breast. They do say the dimpling could be part of the aging  process but again it’s also a worry that surfaces every now and then x
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Do like that last line describing your right side Carolyn
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Thanks Gay. I know I’ve got to accept the position, get on with the treatment and start to think more positively x
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Thanks Toxophilite. I had read that they remove a fat pad and separate out the nodes. I’m also sure I read before when I looked into this that a lot depended on the skill of the pathologist as to how many nodes he/she can extract. I’m quite sure the oncologist could have answered my question by saying I only had 11 nodes or that was all that were extracted instead of the answer he gave. I’ve got an appointment with my breast consultant next week so I’ll ask her.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Jan119. Can I ask you a question about your Staging? In your profile you say that with 17 cancerous lymph nodes you are Stage 2 as does another lady who had 14 cancerous lymph nodes. When I look at the staging chart however my 5 out of 11 positive nodes puts me in Stage 3A.
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Thank you Leolady for your very thoughtful and encouraging words. I read the posts on this site every day and it’s great to see so many like you taking the time to help and support others to cope with the fears and worries that this terrible disease throws up. I hope that whatever path of treatment you have to follow will not affect you too badly x
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Thank you Linda for your kind reply. I do follow the posts on here every day and as I said to Leolady I admire so much the ladies like the both of you who are so quick to come on and help others who are worrying or looking for some advice. I find as the chemo goes on I get more despondent in the second week probably because now my hand is not recovering so well from the cannula insertion as it did previously and the loss of my eyelashes is causing problems with eye infections. I know these are probably minor side effects which my mind blows out of proportion. I too am grateful for this site and it never fails to amaze me the amount of people trying to cope with the effects of this awful disease. Agnes x
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Sara08. It’s good to hear from others with the same diagnosis as yourself  as it makes you feel a little less alone on this journey that we’ve unfortunately had to make. As you say your situation and mine are very similar. I see there are 4 of us now on this site with the diagnosis of occult primary breast cancer - LabradorLass, ida74 and you and I. It’s good to have heard from you all.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Deb09. I have occult breast cancer as  I’ve already mentioned on this thread but what worries me is the small number of lymph nodes that were taken out during the axillary clearance I had compared to the much larger number that others like yourself seem to have had taken out. I worry that some cancerous ones may have been left in. I got a very flippant answer from the oncologist when I questioned him why only 11 had been removed to which he replied that I was the only person he’d heard asking why so few when he’s usually asked why so many. That was his sole answer.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn. Only got the report last Tuesday so probably still dwelling too much on it x
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Thanks Dayityrose. It’s just that when  I read so many posts where people rightly say they are glad that they have no node involvement it worries me that I do have x
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: How do you show you like a post Carolyn? Can’t see where on my IPad.
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Sorry Carolyn.It has just appeared all of a sudden at the bottom of the post
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Thanks for that information about your mum Strawbaby.  i’m glad to hear she is doing really well. Your mums’s treatment is so different from mine as I had surgery first, an axillia clearance, as that was the only place the breast cancer cells showed up and was told by the oncologist today that the operation had been very successful and I was ‘cancer free’ but I was now being given the standard package of care ie. chemotherapy, radiotherapy, Letrozole and Bisphosonates. I’m still undecided about whether to have the chemotherapy as I’m on the old side ( in my seventies)
Posts.Title: Worry over positive lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Aliblue. Thanks for asking how I am. Had 4th chemo 10 days ago and although no sickness or nausea wasn’t feeling great. Fed up feeling like this and in two minds whether to continue chemo or not. Reading this week too about all the foods that can help breast cancer spread didn’t exactly cheer me up either. I’m ashamed of myself for feeling like this when I read such positive and encouraging posts from other ladies on this site. Hope you are doing well and hopefully I’ll buck up in the next few days x
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Sara08. I have occult breast cancer too. No tumour was found in my breast either despite a mammogram, an ultrasound, a CT scan and an MRI. A swollen lymph node was spotted though which a biopsy proved to be cancerous. I had surgery on 2nd October to remove underarm nodes. 11 were removed and 5 had cancer in them but I don’t know the size of any. I have just had the 3rd of 6 Fec this week. I’m not having Fec-T because of my age ( 70’S).  After chemo I’ve to get Letrozole and Bisphosonates.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi LabradorLass. I too have primary breast occult cancer. An enlarged lymph node was found under my left arm in August 2017. A CT scan showed no spread and an MRI showed no primary in breast. I had an an axillary node clearance at beginning of October where 5 out of the 11 nodes removed were positive. I then had chemo, 6 cycles of FEC followed by 15 lots of radiotherapy. I am now on Letrozole which is giving me a few aches and pains and disturbed sleep. I was also supposed to have Bisphosonates but I declined because my dentist told me I would need to have at least 5 teeth taken out before I could start them which put me off having them. That and the fact I read somewhere that Bisphosonates only give you a 2 to 3 % chance of stopping cancer spreading into your bones. Must admit though that at the back of my mind lurks a suspicious I may have made the wrong decision. Good to meet others who have the same rare type of breast cancer as mine. Meant also to say I had another MRI in March this year when chemo finished and a mammogram in August, both of which were fine. I now have only to get yearly mammograms.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you ended up in hospital today Sara08 because of sickness due to your chemo. I had my 3rd Fec last Tuesday and today is the first day I’ve felt a bit better. I felt nauseous for a few days, had no appetite and generally felt lousy. Add to that no sleep at all for a few nights followed by another few restless nights filled with one strange dream after another. During this period of feeling lousy I keep saying I’ve had enough and am not having any more cycles. I think also  because I’ve got eye problems - glaucoma, blepharitis and dry eye syndrome losing most of my eyelashes has just caused me to have one eye infection after another which doesn’t help. Hope you’ll be feeling better soon.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi LabradorLass. Sorry to hear about your recurrence after 8 years and your poor mum’s as well. Hope yours gets treated successfully without chemo. It’s always on your mind worrying if it will come back. I used to read breast cancer was one one of the “better” ones to have if you were going to get cancer. I’m beginning to strongly disagree with this when I read daily on Twitter etc about the amount of women whose lives are never the same after their diagnosis and the number who are unfortunate enough to end up with secondaries. But as you say keep smiling and hope for the best.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Grogg. Was interested in your reply to mamma pink regarding radiotherapy. I saw the oncologist for the first time yesterday to discuss radiation after my WLE and further excision to get clear margins and am now waiting on word as to when I will have the planning CT. I told him I was a bit concerned about the time it has taken between the re-excision and seeing him (9 weeks) and the further wait for the CT scan and radiotherapy as I had read somewhere that radiotherapy should be done between 6 and 12 weeks after the lumpectomy. He agreed the timescale was going to be very neat and said he would try to get it hurried up. He also said the re-currence rate for DCIS high grade after WLE and radiotherapy was about 15% and considering 1 in 8 women get breast cancer that wasn't too bad. Glad to see pure Aloe Vera was recommended by your hospital for use during radiotherapy. When I mentioned to the BC nurse that I had brought pure Aloe Vera home from holiday to use she said I should probably use what they recommend which is usually Diprobase. But I have seen that quite a few ladies on forums have recommended it so I will be too. Princesa 8
Posts.Title: Waiting for breast core biopsy results and reading too much into available...

Posts.Content: Hi Dolina. Should have said I got the contrast dye intravenously through a cannula in my hand before getting the CT scan. Hope everything goes well for you and try not to worry too much x
Posts.Title: Trying not to panic, please help.

Posts.Content: Hi again Dolina. I think when nodes are involved a CT scan is given to find out if there has been any spread from them elsewhere. It’s just another part of the procedure to make sure you get the proper treatment. Like you I’d never had one before as last year I had only a lumpectomy for DCIS followed by radiotherapy. You certainly don’t appear dense as you have to ask questions to find out things you don’t know about or are unsure of.
Posts.Title: Trying not to panic, please help.

Posts.Content: Hi Dolina. You get a blood test to check your kidney function before having a CT scan or an MRI.  It’s because you are given a drink containing a contrast Dye before you have the CT scan or MRI and if your kidney function is poor it could damage your kidneys. So it is perfectly normal to have the blood test to check your kidney function is ok before having your CT scan. I had it before my CT scan. I also had an MRI but didn’t need another blood test as had had the one prior to the CT scan. Hope this puts your mind at rest x
Posts.Title: Trying not to panic, please help.

Posts.Content: Hi Sara08! Sorry I put down the wrong figures.. I should have said it was only 2 or 3 ladies with this rare form of cancer that both the consultant and the oncologist said they come across  in a year. Neither of them had named it but my daughter found out it was called Occult  from googling. Unfortunately neither Macmillan nor Cancer Care UK seem to have any information online about it as very few studies have been made on it because it is so rare. I spent last night trying to find out more about it but most of it was in small studies done in various parts of America so I just ended up feeling dissatisfied which wasn’t good for trying to get to sleep. I haven’t really been given any information about it from my consultant and oncologist rather than it’s very rare. Did you get any information about it from yours?
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi! I'm just getting over a wound infection but I've an appointment with the chemo nurse on 22nd Nov. I'm still a bit concerned about chemotherapy as in the oncologist words 'I'm not in the first flush of youth' and the side effects will probably be a bit more  harsh for me but the MDT think I'm fit enough for it. I had DCIS ( precancerous cells) in my other breast  last year and I had a lumpectomy followed by radiotherapy. I'm cheesed off with hospitals and tests but know I'm lucky to get such good treatment. My daughter lives 6 miles away but I see her and her two wee daughters every day.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sara08. Thanks for the information. I had just read last night on one of the American sites about ALND being just as effective as Mastectomy but radiotherapy to the axilla and whole breast was also recommended. My oncologist said my radiotherapy plan was to the axilla, the clavicle and the chest wall but he did not mention the whole breast which I’ll need to ask him about.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sara08. I read your post with great interest because I also have cancer in the lymph nodes but no primary breast tumour. I was also told it was very rare and only about 10 to 12 ladies in my area are diagnosed with it each year. You are the first person I have come across on this site with it. I had an axillary clearance on 5th October and 5 out of 11 nodes taken out were positive. I have to have chemotherapy radiotherapy and Letrozole as it was oestrogen positive. Glad I've  at last come across someone with the same type of this wretched disease as me.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Undergroundbarbie. Glad you feel better now that you know you weren’t totally ignored. Hope your results are favourable when you get them especially as it will be your birthday. Hope you and your husband get out to celebrate. As for indigestion maybe caused by the co- codamol I’m afraid I can’t help you. I was given ibuprofen and paracetamol to take after my surgery but I took the fewest I could because I’ve never liked taking painkillers and they didn’t cause me any indigestion, which can be awful as I’ve had it in the past. Hope you get some relief from it soon. Take care
Posts.Title: Post op disappointment

Posts.Content: Hi Undergroundbarbie! The way in which you were treated falls well short of what it should have been if my experience is anything to go by. I had a wire guided WLE 18 months ago and every step of the way on the day was discussed with me by the consultant radiologist, the surgeon and the anaethitist. The surgeon come to speak to me after the operation to tell me how it had gone and I was given an appointment to see the breast consultant in 10 days to be given the results. The exact same kind of treatment has happened this year when I went in for an axillary clearance.
Posts.Title: Post op disappointment

Posts.Content: I had been feeling quite good the last few days knowing my chemotherapy would soon be finished ( next week should be my 2nd last) but then my spirits dampened when an appointment for an MRI arrived. Because cancer was found in my lymph nodes but not in my breast, part of my treatment plan is a 6 monthly mammogram of that breast to keep an eye on it. When I saw a different doctor other than my consultant on the day of the mammogram she suggested as well as the 6 monthly mammograms I should also have an MRI. I know that I should be grateful that I am receiving such good monitoring but it gets me down at times thinking about the never ending worry that scans and mammograms cause. Sorry for ranting again- think it’s all I seem to do on here.
Posts.Title: Down day
